text: Ha no worries. That's actually really helpful. I hadn't taken a look at additive keyers but had a look at the Steve Wright tutorial I have on them and that will definitely help on a couple off issues Ive been having on keying.

Because we are working on a kids TV and a number of us aren't overly experienced with nuke we are working with a fairly simplified pipeline which does the job for the show we are working on but doesn't exactly do much in terms of expanding our skillset so I'm doing whatever I can in my spare time to push on a bit further than the pipeline we are working on. Will definitely take some time to experiment with the additive keyer. It looks incredibly good for edge and motion blur work.

No worries, happy to help! Yeah its gold, especially if you have a clean blue/green screen to work with. If you're in a position to ask for a clean plate, always do. It helps a lot! Otherwise they're pretty simple to do yourself but you wont get as good of a result
Yeah unfortunately no clean plates and often some pretty uneven green screen in the wide shots.
Yeah with the worst offenders theres no choice but masking it unfortunately. But ibk is usually pretty great for those instances !
